heading: 6.3 Aligning using BWA-MEM
text: now process map reads using bwa mem. Note run time command syntax bwa mem different (easier faster) bwa aln introduced class. alignment process take ~20 min complete depending server load. highly recommended construct commands within shell script generated associated log files redirecting STDOUT described class. make subsequent commands easier, remember can define paths commonly used files/resources script shell variables. example, can define path indexed mm10 genome directory tutorial input files stored (see ). Best practice use absolute rather relative path defining variables, ensure script behave similarly matter located filesystem.need export variable want add current shell persist sessions. Since script runs subshell continuous session unique variables, ’s necessary export variables within .now familiar, defined can call paths script/shell entering special character $ followed variable name shown . following command run bwa mem stream sam file samtools view, automatically convert bam file. can use design .Note -t 8 multithreaded processing improve speed. $GENOME specifies location reference genome use. $DATA/Naive_H3K27ac_1.fastq $DATA/Naive_H3K27ac_2.fastq specifies location reads. step take time. Expect program run 20 mins longer depending server load. can add nohup front command, front command running script commands, order assure disconnected server, analysis steps stop.
code:
GENOME=/projects/micb405/analysis/references/mm10/mm10.fa
DATA=/projects/micb405/data/mouse/chip_tutorial# Input a.k.a. control alignment
bwa mem \
  -t 8 \
  $GENOME \
  $DATA/Naive_Input_1.fastq \
  $DATA/Naive_Input_2.fastq \
  | samtools view -h -b - -o Naive_Input.bam

# Treatment a.k.a. immunoprecipitated a.k.a. IP alignment
bwa mem \
  -t 8 \
  $GENOME \
  $DATA/Naive_H3K27ac_1.fastq \
  $DATA/Naive_H3K27ac_2.fastq \
  | samtools view -h -b - -o Naive_H3K27ac.bam

heading: 6.5 Sort, mark duplicates, and index alignments using SAMtools
text: output bwa mem unsorted SAM file. Downstream tools require sorted BAM file input, intermediate step sort index alignment facilitate future steps, similar covered samtools/bcftools tutorial.Repeat treatment file well.
code:
# Tag mates
samtools fixmate -m Naive_Input.bam Naive_Input.fixmate.bam
# Position sort for markdup
samtools sort Naive_Input.fixmate.bam -o Naive_Input.fixmate.sort.bam
# Mark duplicates. Note that you don't have to remove them as this is done by MACS2 automatically
samtools markdup -S Naive_Input.fixmate.sort.bam Naive_Input.markdup.bam
# Sort again
samtools sort Naive_Input.markdup.bam -o Naive_Input.final.bam
# Index BAM
samtools index Naive_Input.final.bam

heading: 6.7 Call peaks using MACS2
text: peak calling, necessary sample data set, well control data set. MACS2 offers option perform regular (narrow) broad peak-calling, case, regular peak calling, however instructions similar broad peak-calling just add additional flag --broad command.call peaks sample Naive_H3K27ac.final.bam using Naive_Input.final.bam control (background). sorted, duplicate-marked bam files samples, can perform MACS2 peakcalling like :-t treatment IP (ImmunoPrecipitated) aligned dup-marked bam fileThe -c control INPUT aligned dup-marked bam fileThe -f indicates input file type (BAM paired-end BAMPE case)-g indicates effective genome size (precomputed mm10 provided mm)-n prefix give output filesThe -B indicates program create BedGraph (.bdg) file resultsThe -q FDR cutoff call peaks
code:
macs2 callpeak \
  -t Naive_H3K27ac.final.bam \
  -c Naive_Input.final.bam \
  -f BAMPE \
  -g mm \
  -n Naive_H3K27ac \
  -B \
  -q 0.01

heading: 8.3.4 Sample Clustering
text: distribution RNA Seq data highly skewed, high abundance genes many low abundance genes, helpful transform data visualize clustering. DESeq2 comes function rlog(), log-transforms count data. transformation, can use PCA identify samples similar group one independent variables (case, single variable can take “control” “treated”).distance matrix another way examine samples cluster. code chunk calculates distances sample maps colour palette (defined colorRampPalette) onto similar samples display darker colours.samples don’t cluster together like expect , check batch effects.

rld <- rlog(dds)
plotPCA(rld, intgroup = "condition")

         clustering_distance_rows = sample_dists,
         clustering_distance_cols = sample_dists, 
         col = colours)

heading: 10.1 Setting up for GO term enrichment
text: Create new script R markdown project used DESeq2 tutorial install load required packages. Since Bioconductor packages, install must use BiocManager::install().Load necessary packages.Copy significant results DESeq2 tutorial new file modifying.row names significant genes DEseq2 tutorial mouse Ensembl Gene IDs. Convert Ensemble Gene IDs rownames Entrez IDs new column (add symbols !).Create non-redundant list genes enriched list.Filter significant genes log2FoldChange pull upregulated genes.Create GO hyperGTest object new GOHyperGParams object create upregulated terms gene IDs, looking Biological Process (“BP”) ontology.Convert hyperGTest object viewable format, print top 10 enriched GO terms.
code:
library(AnnotationDbi)
library(org.Mm.eg.db)
library(GO.db)
library(GOstats)
annotated_significant_results <- significant_res
annotated_significant_results$symbol <- mapIds(
  org.Mm.eg.db,
  keys = rownames(annotated_significant_results),
  keytype = "ENSEMBL",
  column = "SYMBOL",
  multiVals = "first"
)## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns
annotated_significant_results$entrez <- mapIds(
  org.Mm.eg.db,
  keys = rownames(annotated_significant_results),
  keytype = "ENSEMBL",
  column = "ENTREZID",
  multiVals = "first"
)## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns
all_genes <- annotated_significant_results %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  pull(entrez) %>% 
  unique()
genes_upregulated <- annotated_significant_results %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  filter(log2FoldChange > 4) %>% 
  pull(entrez) %>% 
  unique()
go_bp_upregulated <- hyperGTest(new("GOHyperGParams",
                                    geneIds = genes_upregulated,
                                    universeGeneIds = all_genes,
                                    annotation = "org.Mm.eg.db",
                                    ontology = "BP",
                                    pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
                                    conditional = FALSE,
                                    testDirection = "over"))
go_bp_upregulated %>% summary() %>% head(10)##        GOBPID       Pvalue OddsRatio   ExpCount Count Size

heading: 12.5.1 Creating of modifying variables with mutate()

  rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(gm = mean(c_across(treated1:untreated4))) %>%

heading: 13.7.5 Using a function to perform a t-test for differentially expressed genes
text: Let’s write simple function calculates p-value expression single gene sampled two different distributions.can repeatedly call function replicate() simulate data set p-values multiple genes (1000).
code:
# Functions ---------------------------------------------------------------
test_differential_gene_expression <- function() {
  single_gene_under_a <- rnorm(n = 3, mean = 4, sd = 1)
  single_gene_under_b <- rnorm(n = 3, mean = 8, sd = 1)
  result <- t.test(single_gene_under_a, single_gene_under_b)
  tidy(result)$p.value
}
p_values_for_differentially_expressed_genes <- tibble(
  differentially_expressed = rep(TRUE, each = 1000),
  p.value = replicate(1000, test_differential_gene_expression())
)

heading: 13.7.7 A function specifying the sampled distributions
text: current function always uses distributions. can create flexible function defining variables define two distributions sample often.Finally, can also provide default values variables <variable> = <default value>.Generate data set p-value 1000 non-differentially expressed genes, .e. whose gene expression conditions shares distribution mean 4, standard deviation 1 3 samples per condition. probability distribution?probability distribution non-differentially expressed genes uniform.
code:
test_differential_gene_expression <- function(n,
                                              mean_a,
                                              sd_a,
                                              mean_b,
                                              sd_b) {
  single_gene_under_a <- rnorm(n = n, mean = mean_a, sd = sd_a)
  single_gene_under_b <- rnorm(n = n, mean = mean_b, sd = sd_b)
  result <- t.test(single_gene_under_a, single_gene_under_b)
  tidy(result)$p.value
}
test_differential_gene_expression <- function(n = 3,
                                              mean_a = 4,
                                              sd_a = 1,
                                              mean_b = 8,
                                              sd_b = 1) {
  single_gene_under_a <- rnorm(n = n, mean = mean_a, sd = sd_a)
  single_gene_under_b <- rnorm(n = n, mean = mean_b, sd = sd_b)
  result <- t.test(single_gene_under_a, single_gene_under_b)
  tidy(result)$p.value
}
p_values_for_non_differentially_expressed_genes <- tibble(
  differentially_expressed = rep(FALSE, each = 1000),
  p.value = replicate(1000,
                      test_differential_gene_expression(3,
                                                        mean_a = 4, sd_a = 1,
                                                        mean_b = 4, sd_b = 1))
) 

p_values_for_non_differentially_expressed_genes %>%

heading: 13.8.3 Function to generate data sets with varying numbers of non-differentially and differentially expressed genes
text: Since execute similar steps generate data sets increasing numbers negatives (non-differentially expressed genes), another opportunity define function. addition, create variable negatives indicates data set (number non-differentially expressed genes) calculate FDR-corrected p-value.Let’s test default data set generated new function shows expected pattern.Let’s create many data sets increasing numbers negatives combine single one.
code:
simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression <- function(
    n_differential     = 1000,
    n_non_differential = 1000) {
  p_values_for_differentially_expressed_genes <- tibble(
    negatives = n_non_differential,
    differentially_expressed = rep(TRUE, each = n_differential),
    p.value = replicate(
      n_differential,
      test_differential_gene_expression(3,
                                        mean_a = 4, sd_a = 1,
                                        mean_b = 8, sd_b = 1))
  )
  
  p_values_for_non_differentially_expressed_genes <- tibble(
    negatives = n_non_differential,
    differentially_expressed = rep(FALSE, each = n_non_differential),
    p.value = replicate(
      n_non_differential,
      test_differential_gene_expression(3,
                                        mean_a = 4, sd_a = 1,
                                        mean_b = 4, sd_b = 1))
  )
  
  bind_rows(p_values_for_non_differentially_expressed_genes,
            p_values_for_differentially_expressed_genes) %>% 
    mutate(p.adj = p.adjust(p.value, method = "fdr"))
}
data_set <- simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression()

data_set %>%
  mutate(differentially_expressed = factor(differentially_expressed,
                                           levels = c("TRUE", "FALSE"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = p.value, fill = differentially_expressed)) +
  geom_histogram(boundary = 0, binwidth = 0.05)
data_set %>%
  mutate(differentially_expressed = factor(differentially_expressed,
                                           levels = c("TRUE", "FALSE"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = p.adj, fill = differentially_expressed)) +
  geom_histogram(boundary = 0, binwidth = 0.05)
set.seed(212)
data_set <- bind_rows(
  simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression(n_non_differential = 1000),
  simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression(n_non_differential = 2000),
  simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression(n_non_differential = 3000),
  simulate_p_values_for_gene_expression(n_non_differential = 4000)
)

heading: 13.9 Independent filtering
text: counteract loss many true positives, {DESeq2} removes tests unlikely show significant differences. Genes low counts prone high dispersion fall category. {DESeq2} empirically determines quantile returns largest numbers rejections (.e. adjusted p-value < 0.05).load Pasilla count metadata read_csv(). {DESeq2} requirements, need convert first column data frame row names column_to_rownames().work {DESeq2}, need convert data frame matrix use construct DESeq object. Finally, define value independent variable condition representing reference/control relevel().pre-filter data set removing genes less 10 counts across samples increase processing speed.Let’s perform {DESeq2} model fitting define \(\alpha\) 0.5 determine results.{DESeq2} automatically performs independent filtering. can extract information metadata DESeq object.can use geom_point() create scatterplot number rejects vs. quantiles. can provide specific aesthetics geom instead ggplot(), latter used universally geoms.Next can provide fitted_line geom_line().Finally, can visualize filter threshold {DESeq2} determined vertical line using geom_vline().many options customize {ggplot2} plot . want add custom labels axes labs() many cases.can also modify general look plot applying theme. {ggplot2} provides number default themes can install additional packages like {ggthemes} options. apply one default themes, theme_bw().
code:
counts <- read_csv("pasilla_gene_counts.csv") %>% 
  column_to_rownames("gene_id")
metadata <- read_csv("pasilla_metadata.csv") %>% 
  column_to_rownames("file")
counts <- as.matrix(counts)

deseq <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(
  countData = counts,
  colData = metadata,
  design = ~ condition
)## converting counts to integer mode## Warning in DESeqDataSet(se, design = design, ignoreRank): some variables in
## design formula are characters, converting to factors
deseq$condition <- relevel(deseq$condition, ref = "untreated")

deseq## class: DESeqDataSet 
## dim: 14599 7 
## metadata(1): version
## assays(1): counts
## rownames(14599): 0000003 0000008 ... 0261574 0261575
## rowData names(0):
## colnames(7): treated1 treated2 ... untreated3 untreated4
## colData names(2): condition type
keep <- rowSums(counts(deseq)) >= 10
deseq <- deseq[keep, ]
deseq <- DESeq(deseq)
deseq_results <- results(deseq, alpha = 0.05)
independent_filtering_data <- metadata(deseq_results)$filterNumRej
independent_filtering_data$fitted_line <- metadata(deseq_results)$lo.fit$y
filter_threshold <- metadata(deseq_results)$filterTheta

metadata(deseq_results)$filterThreshold## 13.57143% 
##  4.890954
independent_filtering_data %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = theta, y = numRej))
independent_filtering_data %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = theta, y = numRej)) +
  geom_line(aes(x = theta, y = fitted_line), colour = "red")
independent_filtering_data %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = theta, y = numRej)) +
  geom_line(aes(x = theta, y = fitted_line), colour = "red") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = filter_threshold)
